It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Just try the best you can to answer the questions. If they help to answer the question.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1920, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaire

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Life: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Really Do?" is still being completed. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ).

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

- Pioneer health conditions

- Pioneer education and childhood
- Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

University of Saskatchewan,

Saskatoon, Sask.
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person submitting this questionnaire:

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. The extra sheets of paper, if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions, don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events. If they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1897, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires:

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled Pioneer Picti What Did You Answer This, and Would Be Willing To Do So? Please Put A Check Mark Here And We Will Be Sent To You.

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please Mark The Ones You Would Be Willing To Answer.

All Questionnaires:

- Pioneer health conditions
- Pioneer housing, life, sports and recreation

- Pioneer farming experience

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent records of our province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

3. Date ......................................................... July 14th, 1953
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country) Buffalo, New York, U.S.A.
5. What was your father's name and occupation? Henry James Hunt Carpenter
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year) March, 1898
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible. January and February, 1898 Toronto, Ontario.
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you were under 18 years of age.) I was nine months old.
9. What were your reasons for coming West? My parents brought me. They felt there were more opportunities in a new country.
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?) My father and uncle had made a trip out West out of curiosity the year previous.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

Relatives in Ontario thought the move a foolish one.
Had I learned of cold winters and other hardships, where one had to pioneer.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?
Father, Mother and Father's Brother

13. What means of transportation did you use?
C.P.R.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.). Can't Remember anything that Long ago.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?
With friends on a farm about ten miles North of Wolesley, Saskatchewan.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?
Pathepoarked on a farm as a hired man.

17. Name of Wolesley, Bigeye, Saskatchewan, Regina, Qu'Appelle and Indian Head.
Neither any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1924? What reasons did they have for moving?

There may have been isolated cases. However there did not appear to be very much in the way of migration.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930s? Did many return?

Quite a number moved during the Thirties. The reason being that Government Agents persuaded them to move from sub-marginal land. A number did return with the improvement in rainfall.
